definitions: officially register oneself or another person for participation in a course, program, or institution
formally admit someone as a member of an organization or group
examples: Students must enrol before the semester begins next Monday
She decided to enrol in evening classes after work
The club will enrol new members during the annual meeting
They enrolled him in their exclusive society last year

definitions: officially register oneself or another person for participation in a course, program, or institution
formally admit someone as a member of an organization or group
examples: Students must enroll before the semester begins next Monday
She decided to enroll in evening classes after work
The club will enroll new members during the annual meeting
They enrolled him in their exclusive society last year

definitions: preserve or protect something valued such as a right or principle in a formal document or law
place a sacred object or revered person's remains in a shrine for veneration
examples: The constitution enshrines basic human rights for all citizens
These principles were enshrined in international law decades ago
The monks enshrined the sacred relics in the temple
They enshrined his remains in the cathedral yesterday morning

definitions: force someone into slavery by depriving them of freedom and compelling them to work without pay
dominate or control someone completely through addiction, obsession, or overwhelming influence
examples: Colonial powers enslaved millions of people throughout history
The invaders enslaved the entire population after conquering the region
Technology can enslave us if we become too dependent
She felt enslaved by her overwhelming debt and obligations

definitions: happen or occur afterward as a consequence or result of something
examples: A heated debate ensued after the controversial announcement yesterday
Chaos ensued when the power suddenly went out everywhere
Legal battles will likely ensue from this disputed contract
Silence ensued after she made her shocking revelation

definitions: make certain that something will occur or be the case by taking necessary actions
guarantee the safety or protection of someone or something through preventive measures
examples: Please ensure all doors are locked before leaving tonight
The manager ensured that deadlines were met every month
Security measures ensure the safety of all passengers aboard
Insurance policies ensure financial protection against unexpected losses

definitions: involve something as a necessary or inevitable part or consequence of an action or situation
legally restrict the inheritance of property to a specified succession of heirs
examples: This job entails working long hours including weekends regularly
The project will entail significant costs beyond our budget
The estate was entailed to the eldest son only
He entailed his property to prevent its division later

definitions: come or go into a place, building, or enclosed area
become involved in or start participating in an activity, situation, or state
input or record data or information into a computer system or document
officially register or submit something for a competition, examination, or formal process
examples: She entered the room quietly without disturbing anyone
The train entered the tunnel at high speed yesterday
The company entered the Asian market last year successfully
He entered politics after retiring from his business career
Please enter your password to access the secure system
The clerk entered all transactions into the accounting database
She entered the marathon despite her recent injury recovery
Students must enter the examination before the deadline expires

definitions: provide amusement or enjoyment through performance, activities, or engaging content for an audience
give consideration to an idea, suggestion, or possibility without necessarily accepting it
receive and provide hospitality to guests in one's home or at social events
examples: The comedian entertained the crowd for two hours straight
Children's parties often entertain kids with games and magic
The board will entertain proposals from all interested parties
She refused to entertain such ridiculous notions any longer
They entertain guests every weekend at their country estate
The ambassador entertained foreign dignitaries at the embassy reception

definitions: attract or tempt someone by offering pleasure, advantage, or reward to influence their behavior
examples: The store enticed customers with huge discounts this weekend
Free samples entice shoppers to try new products regularly
She tried to entice him away from his current employer
The warm weather enticed us outside for a long walk

definitions: give someone the legal right or qualification to receive or do something specific
give a title or name to a book, article, or other creative work
examples: Your membership entitles you to exclusive discounts and benefits
This ticket entitles the bearer to one free admission
She entitled her memoir 'Days of Thunder and Rain'
The artist entitled the painting after completing it yesterday

definitions: fill someone with wonder and delight so completely that they become captivated or mesmerized
put someone into a trance-like state through hypnosis or overwhelming sensory experience
examples: The magician's performance entranced the entire audience completely
She was entranced by the beautiful sunset over the ocean
The hypnotist entranced volunteers from the audience within minutes
The rhythmic drumming entranced listeners into a meditative state

definitions: catch or hold someone or something in a trap or confined space from which escape is difficult
trick or deceive someone into committing a crime or compromising action to incriminate them
examples: The hunters entrapped the wild boar using traditional methods
Fallen debris entrapped several miners underground for hours yesterday
The undercover agents entrapped him into selling illegal substances
She felt entrapped by their elaborate scheme against her

definitions: establish an attitude, habit, or belief so firmly that change becomes very difficult or unlikely
dig trenches or establish a defensive military position using fortifications and earthworks
examples: These outdated practices have become entrenched over many decades
Corruption was deeply entrenched in the political system there
The soldiers entrenched themselves along the strategic hillside position
The army entrenched their position before the enemy arrived

definitions: assign the responsibility of doing something or caring for someone or something to a person
examples: She entrusted her children to her sister's care temporarily
The board entrusted him with managing the entire project
I entrust this important task to you with complete confidence
They entrusted their life savings to the investment firm

definitions: mention or list things one by one in a systematic and organized manner
count or calculate the exact number of items in a collection or group
examples: The report enumerates all violations found during the inspection
She carefully enumerated each reason for her decision yesterday
Census workers enumerate the population every ten years nationwide
The inventory system enumerates all items in stock automatically

definitions: wrap up, cover, or surround something completely as if with a covering or envelope
surround and conceal someone or something entirely with a substance or atmospheric condition
examples: She carefully enveloped the gift in decorative paper yesterday
The blanket enveloped the sleeping child in warm comfort
Thick fog enveloped the entire city throughout the morning
Darkness gradually enveloped the landscape as evening fell slowly

definitions: imagine or visualize something as a future possibility or potential reality in one's mind
examples: She envisions a world without poverty or hunger anywhere
The architect envisioned a sustainable building design using renewable materials
It's difficult to envision success without proper planning first
They envisioned themselves living abroad after retirement next year

definitions: feel discontent or resentful longing aroused by someone else's possessions, qualities, or luck
examples: She secretly envied her sister's natural athletic ability greatly
Many people envy celebrities' glamorous lifestyles without knowing the truth
He envied their freedom to travel whenever they wanted
Don't envy others; focus on your own journey instead

definitions: bond or coat something using epoxy resin adhesive for strong permanent attachment or protection
examples: The technician epoxied the broken parts together yesterday afternoon
They epoxied the metal plates to create waterproof sealing
We need to epoxy these tiles before installing them
The manufacturer epoxies all joints for maximum structural strength

definitions: be the same as something else in quantity, size, degree, value, or status
match or rival someone's achievement, performance, or quality through comparable accomplishment
examples: Two plus two equals four in basic arithmetic everywhere
Her dedication equals that of any professional athlete today
No one could equal her record-breaking performance last year
This achievement equals the best in company history easily

definitions: make things equal or uniform in amount, status, or quality by adjustment or redistribution
score a goal or point that makes the score equal in a competitive game
examples: The new policy equalises pay between different departments nationwide
Technology helps equalise educational opportunities for all students everywhere
The team equalised in the final minutes of play
United equalised just before halftime with a spectacular goal

definitions: make things equal or uniform in amount, status, or quality by adjustment or redistribution
score a goal or point that makes the score equal in a competitive game
examples: The new policy equalizes pay between different departments nationwide
Technology helps equalize educational opportunities for all students everywhere
The team equalized in the final minutes of play
United equalized just before halftime with a spectacular goal

definitions: consider one thing to be the same as or equivalent to another in some respect
state that two mathematical expressions are equal or represent the same value
examples: Many people equate success with wealth, but that's misleading
Don't equate silence with agreement in these important discussions
The formula equates energy with mass times light speed squared
We can equate these two expressions to solve for x

definitions: supply someone or something with the necessary items, tools, or apparatus for a particular purpose
prepare someone intellectually or emotionally with the skills or qualities needed for a situation
examples: The company equipped all employees with new laptop computers
They equipped the laboratory with state-of-the-art research instruments yesterday
The training program equips students with essential job skills
Life experiences equipped her to handle difficult challenges confidently

definitions: destroy something completely by removing all traces, especially to eliminate disease, pests, or social problems
examples: Scientists work tirelessly to eradicate deadly diseases worldwide permanently
The government promised to eradicate poverty within ten years
Farmers use various methods to eradicate invasive weed species
The program aims to eradicate illiteracy in rural areas

definitions: remove written or drawn marks from a surface by rubbing or using an eraser
delete or remove recorded data from a computer, tape, or other storage medium
remove or eliminate something from memory, existence, or consideration completely
examples: She erased the pencil marks from her sketch carefully
Please erase the whiteboard before the next class begins
The virus erased all files from the computer system
He accidentally erased the important recording from his device
Time cannot erase the memories of that wonderful summer
The new evidence erased all doubts about her innocence

definitions: construct a building, wall, or other upright structure in a particular place
raise something to an upright or vertical position from a horizontal or lowered state
examples: Workers erected the new office building in six months
The city erected a monument honoring fallen soldiers yesterday
They erected the tent quickly before the storm arrived
The crew erected scaffolding around the historic building carefully

definitions: gradually wear away or destroy the surface of something through natural forces like wind or water
gradually weaken, diminish, or destroy something abstract like confidence, power, or value over time
examples: Ocean waves constantly erode the coastal cliffs each year
Heavy rainfall eroded the hillside causing dangerous mudslides yesterday
Inflation continues to erode the purchasing power of savings
Repeated scandals eroded public trust in the institution significantly

definitions: make a mistake or be incorrect in one's judgment, opinion, or action
examples: To err is human, but forgiveness is divine indeed
The judge erred in dismissing the case so quickly
It's better to err on the side of caution here
She rarely errs in her mathematical calculations these days

definitions: burst forth or release lava, ash, and gases violently from a volcano or similar geological feature
break out or occur suddenly and dramatically, especially violence, disorder, or disease
suddenly express or display strong emotion, especially anger or excitement in an uncontrolled way
examples: The volcano erupted without warning, endangering nearby villages immediately
Mount Vesuvius erupted and buried Pompeii in ancient times
Violence erupted in the streets after the controversial verdict
A heated argument erupted between the two rival groups
The crowd erupted in cheers when their team scored
She erupted in anger after hearing the false accusations

definitions: increase rapidly in extent, intensity, or severity, especially regarding conflict or problematic situations
travel upward on a moving staircase or escalator in a building or station
examples: The conflict escalated into a full-scale war within months
Tensions escalated dramatically after the failed peace negotiations yesterday
Passengers escalated to the departure level using automatic stairs
She escalated quickly to catch her connecting flight upstairs

definitions: break free from confinement, control, or danger and get away to safety or freedom
avoid or succeed in not experiencing something unpleasant, harmful, or unwanted
leak or issue from a container or confined space gradually or accidentally
examples: The prisoners escaped through a tunnel they dug secretly
The family escaped the burning building just in time
She narrowly escaped serious injury in the car accident
He escaped punishment by blaming others for his mistakes
Gas escaped from the damaged pipe throughout the night
A sigh escaped her lips when she heard the news

definitions: deliberately avoid using, doing, or participating in something as a matter of principle or preference
examples: The monk eschews all worldly pleasures and material possessions
She eschews social media to maintain her privacy completely
Many investors eschew high-risk ventures despite potential rewards
The author eschews complex prose for simple, clear writing

definitions: accompany someone or something somewhere for protection, guidance, or as a mark of respect
examples: Security guards escorted the celebrity through the crowded airport
Police escorted the convoy safely to its destination yesterday
He escorted her to the formal dinner party downtown
The naval ship escorted merchant vessels through dangerous waters

definitions: adopt, support, or advocate a cause, belief, or way of life publicly and enthusiastically
marry someone in a formal ceremony according to traditional or religious customs
examples: The candidate espouses progressive policies on climate change actively
Many philosophers espoused democratic ideals during the Enlightenment period
In medieval times, nobles espoused partners for political alliances
The prince espoused the princess in a grand ceremony

definitions: catch sight of or glimpse something or someone, especially from a distance or unexpectedly
examples: She espied a ship on the distant horizon yesterday
The scout espied enemy troops moving through the valley
He espied his old friend across the crowded marketplace
From the tower, they espied riders approaching from afar

definitions: set up an organization, system, or set of rules on a firm or permanent basis
show something to be true or certain by determining the facts through investigation
achieve permanent acceptance or recognition for something, especially oneself in a role or position
examples: The company established its headquarters in New York City
They established new safety protocols after the incident occurred
Scientists established a clear link between smoking and cancer
The investigation established his innocence beyond any reasonable doubt
She quickly established herself as a leading expert worldwide
The artist established his reputation through years of dedication

definitions: respect and admire someone or something for their qualities, achievements, or high moral standards
examples: His colleagues highly esteem him for his integrity always
She esteems honesty above all other virtues in life
The community esteems teachers who dedicate themselves to education
We esteem those who sacrifice for others' benefit daily

definitions: roughly calculate or judge the value, number, quantity, or extent of something without exact measurement
form an approximate judgment or opinion regarding the worth, nature, or quality of something
examples: Engineers estimate the project will cost ten million dollars
She estimated the distance at roughly five miles away
Experts estimate that unemployment will rise next quarter significantly
It's difficult to estimate the impact of these changes

definitions: cause someone to be no longer friendly or affectionate due to disagreement, conflict, or emotional distance
examples: Years of arguments estranged him from his family completely
Political differences estranged the once close friends permanently
Her behavior gradually estranged all her former colleagues
The scandal estranged many supporters from the organization entirely

definitions: cut or carve a design or pattern into a hard surface using acid or a sharp tool
impress or fix something deeply and permanently in someone's mind or memory
examples: The artist etched intricate designs onto the copper plate
They etched their initials into the old oak tree
The tragic event etched itself into her memory forever
His words were etched in my mind for years

definitions: remove people from a dangerous place to somewhere safe in an organized urgent manner
remove air, water, or other contents from a container or space to create emptiness
examples: Authorities evacuated residents before the hurricane arrived yesterday evening
The building was evacuated after the bomb threat came
The pump evacuates water from the flooded basement quickly
Scientists evacuate air from the chamber for the experiment

definitions: escape or avoid something or someone by cleverness, trickery, or illegal means
avoid giving a direct answer to a question or dealing with a matter directly
examples: The fugitive evaded capture for three months straight successfully
She evaded taxes by hiding income in offshore accounts
Politicians often evade difficult questions during press conferences
He evaded the issue by changing the subject repeatedly

definitions: form an idea of the amount, value, or quality of something through careful systematic assessment
examples: Teachers evaluate student performance through various assessment methods regularly
The committee will evaluate all proposals before making decisions
Doctors evaluate patients thoroughly before recommending treatment plans
We need to evaluate the risks before proceeding further

definitions: preach the Christian gospel to others with the aim of converting them to Christianity
advocate or promote something enthusiastically, especially a cause, belief, or product
examples: Missionaries traveled worldwide to evangelize remote communities for decades
The preacher evangelizes at street corners every Sunday morning
Tech enthusiasts evangelize the benefits of artificial intelligence constantly
She evangelizes for sustainable living practices wherever she goes

definitions: turn from liquid into vapor by the natural process of increasing temperature or exposure
gradually cease to exist, disappear, or lose substance like vapor dissipating
examples: Water evaporates quickly under the hot desert sun
The puddles evaporated completely after the rain stopped yesterday
Her enthusiasm evaporated when she heard the bad news
Their savings evaporated during the economic crisis last year

definitions: occur as a result or in the end, especially after a lengthy process or series of events
examples: The negotiations eventuated in a successful peace agreement finally
Their long courtship eventuated in marriage last summer
Nothing significant eventuated from the lengthy committee meetings
The research eventuated in several important scientific discoveries

definitions: expel someone from a property or dwelling by legal process for breach of conditions
examples: The landlord evicted tenants for not paying rent repeatedly
The court ordered to evict squatters from the building
They were evicted from their apartment after numerous complaints
The sheriff arrived to evict the family yesterday morning

definitions: be or show evidence of something's existence, truth, or presence through facts or signs
examples: The fossils evidence prehistoric life in this region clearly
Her success evidences years of hard work and dedication
Blood tests evidenced the presence of the rare disease
These documents evidence widespread corruption in the department
